occurrences.line_text: Of all which I yet glad to beare the packe,
Full glad and ioyous then young Tristram grew,
Glad would I surely be, thou courteous Squire,
For though she were right glad, so rid to bee
Glad of that easement, though it were but small;
Right glad was Calepine to be so rid
Ne she lesse glad; for she so wisely did,
Whereof exceeding glad, he to him drew,
Were glad to heare of that aduenture new,
He glad of life, and willing eke to wreake
Thereof false Turpin was full glad and faine,
Whereof right glad they seem'd, and offer made
Whereof they both full glad and blyth did rest,
And with greene boughes decking a gloomy glade,
But farre within, as in a hollow glade,
At last he came vnto a gloomy glade,
Or bathe him in a fountaine by some couert glade.
That none durst passen through that perilous glade.
Within that wood there was a couert glade,
Where was their dwelling, in a pleasant glade,
Which she had gathered in a shadie glade
And of their louely fellowship full glade,
Thrust to an Hynd within some couert glade,
For wofull wight, chose out a gloomy glade,
We chaunst to come foreby a couert glade
They met together in that luckelesse glade;
Farre in the forrest by a hollow glade,
Till that at length vnto a woody glade
Which may her feeble leaues with comfort glade.
Of his successe and gladfull victory:
Some gladfull newes and sure intelligence,
His bands, and follow'd him with gladfull glee,
Spending their ioyous dayes and gladfull nights,
With gladfull hast, in hope of him to get
The gladfull blessing of posteritie,
Soone as they spide her, Lord what gladfull glee
Full merrily, and making gladfull glee,
With gladfull speaches, and with louely cheare,
And gladly did them guide, till to the Hall they came.
To read those bookes; who gladly graunted their desire.
Vpon them gladly would haue prov'd his might,
She gladly graunted it: then he straight way
In dread of death, his heasts did gladly heare,
It gladly did accept, as he did say.
Ne would I gladly combate with mine host,
She gladly did of that same babe accept,
The which full gladly they did take in glee,
Did gladly hearken to his graue beheast,
The knight full gladly soone agreed thereto,
With sober gladnesse, and myld modestie,
She weend, and wondrous gladnesse to her hart applyde.
The sight whereof did all with gladnesse fill:
They shouted loud, and signes of gladnesse all did shew.
And streight went forth his gladnesse to partake
From highest heauen, in gladsome companee,
Where gladsome Guyon salied forth to land,
Vnto the gladsome port of her intent:
Thence to depart with glee and gladsome chere.
There with great ioyance and with gladsome glee,
Shew gladsome countenaunce nor pleasaunt glee:
And rest her selfe, as in a gladsome port,
Which when he saw, the glaiue which he did wield
Which hight of him Glamorgan, there him slew:
Who soone as on that knight his eye did glance,
Which battring, downe it on the church doth glance,
Some framd faire lookes, glancing like euening lights,
The glauncing sparkles through her beuer glared,
Like two great Beacons, glared bright and wyde,
Those glaring lampes were set, that made a dreadfull shade.
And well could file his tongue as smooth as glas;
Drunke of the streame, as cleare as cristall glas;
And all embrewd in bloud, his eyes did shine as glas.
And this bright Angels towre quite dims that towre of glas.
Whose image she had seene in Venus looking glas.
Like to the world it selfe, and seem'd a world of glas.
Glauncing vnwares in charmed looking glas,
On which the waues, glittering like Christall glas,
Which see not perfet things but in a glas:
Then linger, till the glasse be all out ronne?
A looking glasse, right wondrously aguiz'd,
Ybuilded all of glasse, by Magicke powre,
That in his face, as in a looking glasse,
Long since in that enchaunted glasse she saw.
Pure in aspect, and like to christall glasse,
Yet glasse was not, if one did rightly deeme,
But being faire and brickle, likest glasse did seeme.
Yet is that glasse so gay, that it can blynd
Such was the glassie globe that Merlin made,
He built by art vpon the glassy See
Her aged Nurse, whose name was Glauce hight,
That when old Glauce saw, for feare least blame
Old Glauce cast, to cure this Ladies griefe:
Then Glauce thus, Let not it thee offend,
Glauce, what needs this colourable word,
But read (said Glauce) thou Magitian
In th'euening late old Glauce thither led
Till that old Glauce gan with sharpe repriefe,
But lookt on Glauce grim, who woxe afeard
He for reuenge had guiltlesse Glauce slaine:
Such vs'd wise Glauce to that wrathfull knight,
For ought that Glauce could or doe or say.
But Glauce, seeing all that chaunced there,
When Glauce thus gan wisely all vpknit;
Till Glauce thus; Faire Sir, be nought dismayd
Light Doto, wanton Glauce, and Galene glad.
And seeming still to smile, Glauconome,
And Glaucus, that wise southsayes vnderstood;
And laying both his hands vpon his glaue,
Vnto the bush her eye did suddein glaunce,
That as the Sunny beames do glaunce and glide
A long the shore, as swift as glaunce of eye,
Did roll too highly, and too often glaunce,
Still did she roue at her with crafty glaunce
Guided thy glaunce, to bring his will to pas:
The wicked steele through his left side did glaunce;
Whom hauing slaine, through luckles arrowes glau[n]ce
By Priamond, that with vnluckie glaunce,
His rouing eie did on the Lady glaunce,
The glaunce whereof their dimmed eies would daze,
Sir Satyrane, that glaunces might not glyde:
And glauncing downe his shield, from blame him fairely blest.
And how he slew with glauncing dart amisse
Like glauncing light of Phoebus brightest ray;
Themselues in vaine: for since that glauncing sight,
But glauncing by forth passed forward right;
And glauncing from his scaly necke, did glyde
That glauncing fire out of the yron plaid;
On his broad shield, bit not, but glauncing fell
And glauncing on his helmet, made a large
And glauncing downe would not his owner byte:
Glauncing vnwares in charmed looking glas,
And glauncing fell to ground, but him annoyed naught.
But glauncing on the tempred mettall, brast
Which when she saw, with sodaine glauncing eye,
That glauncing downe his thigh, the purple bloud forth drew.
And with wide glauncing words, one day she thus him proued.
The glauncing sparkles through her beuer glared,
That glauncing on her shoulder plate, it bit
But glauncing by, deceiu'd him of that he desynd.
Glauncing askew, as if his enemies
The stroke down fro[m]; her head vnto her shoulder glaunst.
So sorely he her strooke, that thence it glaunst
Her ventayle shard away, and thence forth glaunst
Ran fierce at me, that fire glaunst from his horses hoofe.
Glaunst swiftly by; like to that heauenly sparke,
With bils and glayues making a dreadfull luster;
Of life him selfe, and hart-strings of an ï¿½ fï¿½EUR gle riued.
Their vapour vaded, shew their golden gleames,
Mongst which crept litle Angels through the glittering gleames.
Whom all the people follow with great glee,
Most goodly glee and louely blandishment
But nor for gold nor glee will I abide
And entertaines with comely courteous glee,
And him salute with well beseeming glee:
The whiles the other Ladies mind their merry glee.
And comely glee of many gracious
Their goodly entertainement and great glee:
Thence to depart with glee and gladsome chere.
Vnto the prison in her ioyous glee,
There with great ioyance and with gladsome glee,
Shew gladsome countenaunce nor pleasaunt glee:
His bands, and follow'd him with gladfull glee,
With whom great feast and goodly glee he fond,
But fild with courage and with ioyous glee,
For guiftes of gold, or any worldly glee,
Where goodly glee and feast to them she made,
Yet had no meanes to comfort, nor procure her glee.
The which full gladly they did take in glee,
A faire young Mayden, full of comely glee;
With all the courteous glee and goodly feast,
Soone as they spide her, Lord what gladfull glee
Were met, to make their sports and merrie glee,
Full merrily, and making gladfull glee,
As he this way comming from feastfull glee,
There in a gloomy hollow glen she found
With heary glib deform'd, and meiger face,
That as the Sunny beames do glaunce and glide
Through both whose borders swiftly downe it glides,
Whom soone as Talus spide by glims of night,
There by th'vncertaine glimse of starry night,
That the bright glister of their beames cleare
For it did glister like the golden sand,
In glistering armes right goodly well beseene,
And all their tops bright glistering with gold,
And glisters wide, as als' of wondrous Bath,
With golden aygulets, that glistred bright,
That glistred all with gold and glorious shew,
To that most glorious house, that glistreth bright
And looked in: his glistring armor made
In glistring gold, and peerelesse pretious stone:
And hurld his glistring beames through gloomy aire.
For so exceeding shone his glistring ray,
The golden Sunne his glistring head gan shew,
That with his glistring armes does ill agree;
Those glistring armes, that heauen with light did fill,
Whose glistring glosse darkned with filthy dust,
Glistring in armes and battailous aray,
There, as in glistring glory she did sit,
Their fruit were golden apples glistring bright,
In glistring steele, and strongly fortifide:
Glistring in armes and warlike ornament,
And all about, the glistring walles were hong
With that her glistring helmet she vnlaced;
Pactolus glistring with his golden flood,
Glistring like gold, amongst the plights enrold,
Her glorious glitterand light doth all mens eyes amaze.
His glitterand armour shined farre away,
Soone as those glitterand armes he did espye,
Eftsoones himselfe in glitterand armes he dight,
And his owne armes when glittering he did spy,
On which the waues, glittering like Christall glas,
With glittering spangs, that did like starres appeare,
Mongst which crept litle Angels through the glittering gleames.
The stedfast globe of earth, as it for feare did quake.
Such was the glassie globe that Merlin made,
Like sparke of fire that from the anduile glode.
Like as a gloomie cloud, the which doth beare
A litle glooming light, much like a shade,
Scarsely had Phoebus in the glooming East
Now glooming sadly, so to cloke her matter;
And hurld his glistring beames through gloomy aire.
And with greene boughes decking a gloomy glade,
At last he came vnto a gloomy glade,
A gloomy groue of mirtle trees did rise,
There in a gloomy hollow glen she found
With perly deaw, and th'Earthes gloomy shade
By that the gloomy euening on them fell,
For wofull wight, chose out a gloomy glade,
Hath to the gloomy world it selfe bewray'd,
Did vnderneath them make a gloomy shade;
Therefore they Glorian call that glorious flowre,
Long mayst thou Glorian liue, in glory and great powre.
That greatest Gloriana to him gaue,
But either Gloriana let her chuse,
Great Gloriana, greatest Maiesty,
(Saue onely Glorianaes heauenly hew
Forthwith to court of Gloriane I sped,
Of Gloriane great Queene of glory bright,
till time of Gloriane.
Which he had vndertane to Gloriane;
Great Gloriane, that Tyrant to fordoo,
Whether in beauties glorie did exceede;
Thought all their glorie vaine in knightly vew,
And to augment the glorie of his guile,
Th'Eternall brood of glorie excellent:
And fild far landes with glorie of his might,
That glorie does to them for guerdon graunt:
In which he hath great glorie wonne, as I heare tell.
And spred his glorie through all countries wide.
Through all this realme, the glorie of her sex,
Great was his power and glorie ouer all,
Reuiuing thought of glorie and of fame,
To hunt for glorie and renowmed praise;
And to aduance his name and glorie more,
And with great glorie both the shield of loue,
For glorie vaine their fellowship to lose,
That much he gan his glorie to enuy,
A stranger knight, that did his glorie shend:
That many wish to win for glorie vaine,
What glorie, or what guerdon hast thou found
Whose glorie is to aide all suppliants pore,
To tell the glorie of the feast that day,
By which that glorie gotten doth appeare.
And them amongst, her glorie to commend,
Dispreds the glorie of her leaues gay;
And eke her champions glorie sounded ouer all.
Her goodly thighes, whose glorie did appeare
Reaping eternall glorie of his restlesse paines.
The glorie of the great, mongst whom I won,
Does all their deeds deface, and dims their glories all.
But for faire Ladies loue, and glories gaine,
That enterprize, for greatest glories gayne.
And beautifull, as glories beames appeare,
Her hart on knight so goodly glorifide,
Admir'd of all the people, and much glorifide.
With great successe, that her hath glorifide,
That warlike feats doest highest glorifie.
As through the world thereby should glorifie his name.
Or Arts, but Oxford thine doth Thame most glorify.
With tryumph entertayn'd and glorifyde,
That glorious fire it kindled in his hart,
To thinke of that true glorious type of thine,
For whose sweete sake that glorious badge he wore,
That greatest Glorious Queene of Faerie lond,
In so ritch weedes and seeming glorious show,
And to the Presence mount; whose glorious vew
To dim the brightnesse of her glorious throne,
Her glorious glitterand light doth all mens eyes amaze.
And is with child of glorious great intent,
But in vaine glorious frayes he litle did delight.
Both glorious brightnesse, and great terrour bred;
To that most glorious house, that glistreth bright
most glorious victory.
And glorious light of her sunshyny face
For which enrolled is your glorious name
Of glorious knighthood, after bloud to thrust,
Great and most glorious virgin Queene aliue,
Hath great or glorious in mortall eye.
So glorious mirrhour of celestiall grace,
And glorious spoiles, purchast in perilous fight:
Vaine glorious Elfe (said he) doest not thou weet,
Embost with massy gold of glorious gift,
For well he weened, that so glorious bayte
Of that most glorious visage ye did vew?
Therefore they Glorian call that glorious flowre,
So greatest and most glorious thing on ground
Cannot your glorious pourtraict figure plaine
Did sparckle forth great light, and glorious did appeare.
That glistred all with gold and glorious shew,
Ne in so glorious spoile themselues embosse;
My glorious Soueraines goodly auncestrie,
Whence all the world deriues the glorious
From her left arme, to rest in glorious victorye.
Her goodly personage and glorious hew,
What boots it boast thy glorious descent,
The roote, and brings forth glorious flowres of fame,
Made him seeme happie for so glorious theft;
Ne desperate of glorious victorie,
And hearts quite robbed with so glorious sight,
Assembled were, that glorious prize to gaine.
That glorious belt did in it selfe containe,
Then did her glorious flowre wex dead and wan,
Which from that goodly glorious flowre proceed,
For though sweet loue to conquer glorious be,
For no intreatie would forgoe so glorious spoyle.
That glorious spoyle of beautie with me lead,
Ne is that same great glorious lampe of light,
And makes them like himselfe in glorious sight,
The glorious picture vanisheth away,
And what a glorious shew he made in all their sights.
For beautie is more glorious bright and clere,
For what hath all that goodly glorious gaze
Wherein ye haue great glory wonne this day,
Proud of such glory and aduancement vaine,
Of victors glory from him snatcht away:
The conquest yours, I yours, the shield, and glory yours.
Of Gloriane great Queene of glory bright,
How dare I thinke such glory to attaine?
That feeble eyes your glory may behold,
Whose glory is in gracious deeds, and ioyes
A pleasing vaine of glory vaine did find,
Great glory and gay spoile sure hast thou got,
Is all his force forlorne, and all his glory donne?
Of loue they euer greater glory bore,
And whom I lust, do heape with glory and renowne?
His glory did enhaunce, and pompous pride display.
There, as in glistring glory she did sit,
That goodly was their glory to behold,
More glory thought to giue life, then decay,
Whose glory shineth as the morning starre,
Through great desire of glory and of fame:
Conceiue such soueraine glory, and great bountihed?
Of Brutus, nor of Britons glory auncient.
Long mayst thou Glorian liue, in glory and great powre.
Where is the Antique glory now become,
Aswell for glory of great valiaunce,
That mortall men her glory should admire
Your glory set, to chace the saluage beasts,
And all their glory to the ground downe flings,
His glory did repose, and credit did maintaine.
Most vertuous virgin, glory be thy meed,
The shyning glory of your soueraigne light,
Their of-spring hath embaste, and later glory shent.
The glory of the later world to spring,
That in all glory and great enterprise,
Ne in small meares containe his glory great,
So shall your glory be aduaunced much,
Fame is my meed, and glory vertues pray.
Euen immortall praise, and glory wyde,
She found, and all their glory quite decayd,
That shall you win more glory, then ye here find gaines.
Loose so immortall glory, and so endlesse gaines.
Their greatest glory, for their rightfull deedes,
Her selfe came in, her glory to partake;
To all, that passe. That shall you glory gaine
Of which he grace and glory wonne alwaies,
Loue hath the glory of his kingdome left,
Sunne of the world, great glory of the sky,
That when thy glory shall be farre displayd
That euer liu'd, and th'onely glory of his might.
Whose glistring glosse darkned with filthy dust,
He much more goodly glosse thereon doth shed,
But told it flames, and hidden it does glow,
And downe both sides two wide long eares did glow,
For he could well his glozing speaches frame
For Steward was excessiue Gluttonie,
And by his side rode loathsome Gluttony,
Such one was Gluttony, the second of that crew.
And glauncing from his scaly necke, did glyde
Sir Satyrane, that glaunces might not glyde:
Past through his eyes, and secretly did glyde
Stayd not, till through his curat it did glyde,
Which glyding through the ayre lights all the heauens darke.
And felly gnarre, vntill dayes enemy
And grimly gnash, threatning reuenge in vaine:
And both did gnash their teeth, & both did threaten life.
And gnashed with his teeth, as if he band
Thereat the feend his gnashing teeth did grate,
He tombling downe, with gnashing teeth did bite
Gnashing his cruell teeth at him in vaine,
Gnashing his grinded teeth with griesly looke,
Still as he rode, he gnasht his teeth, to see
And gnasht his yron tuskes at that displeasing sight.
And gnasht his teeth, and his head at him shooke,
As when a swarme of Gnats at euentide
A cloud of combrous gnattes do him molest,
For vile disdaine and rancour, which did gnaw
Another in her teeth did gnaw a rush:
For fell despight, and gnaw his gealous hart,
On which she fed, and gnawed hungrily,
The gnawing anguish and sharpe gelosy,
But gnawing Gealosie out of their sight
Gnawing her nayles for felnesse and for yre,
Or it in Gnidus be, I wote not well;
And eke vnhable once to stirre or go,
That well he could not touch, nor go, nor stand:
Go gather vp the reliques of thy race,
And how haue seene vnwares. Lo now I go with thee.
Go find some other play-fellowes, mine own sweet boy.
With many rather for to go astray,
Withouten which she could not go vpright;
With his well rigged boate: They go abord,
Doth it consume, and into nothing go,
A womans will, which is disposd to go astray.
Them go to rest. So all vnto their bowres were brought.
But let vs go to seeke my dearest Dame,
Be thou, where euer thou do go or ryde,
As two wild Boares together grapling go,
And streight at him with all his force did go.
But go, which way they list, their guide they haue forlore.
But go thy waies to him, and fro me say,
Being his harts owne wish, and home with him did go.
Out of the wood he rose, and toward them did go.
That all the people where so he did go,
A gushing riuer of blacke goarie blood,
Their greedy vengeaunces, but goary blood,
Vpon a bearded Goat, whose rugged haire,
Or from the Goat her kidde how to conuay;
And like a wilde goate round about did chace,
And like wyld Goates them chaced all about,
The wicked Gobbelines in bloudy field:
Then from her mouth the gobbet she does take,
Full of great lumpes of flesh and gobbets raw,
In which yet trickling bloud and gobbets raw
A monster vile, whom God and man does hate:
God helpe the man so wrapt in Errours endlesse traine.
So forward on his way (with God to frend)
Of highest God, the Lord of life and light;
The God obayde, and calling forth straight way
Or the blind God, that doth me thus amate,
He was, and cared not for God or man a point.
As the God of my life? why hath he me abhord?
For of his wicked pelfe his God he made,
And him as onely God to call vpon,
His cursed hand gainst God, and on his altars daunst.
Till scornd of God and man a shamefull death he dide.
They drawing nigh, vnto their God present
The God himselfe vewing that mirrhour rare,
To God for vengeance cryde continually,
Their God himselfe, grieu'd at my libertie,
We met that villen (God from him me blesse)
But God you neuer let his charmed speeches heare.
But thankt be God, and her encrease so euermore.
Of God, of grace, of iustice, of free will,
Almightie God her gaue such powre, and puissance great.
The grace of God he layd vp still in store,
The images of God in earthly clay;
That God to vs forgiueth euery howre
Ah dearest God me graunt, I dead be not defould.
Of God and goodnesse was his meditation.
For God he often saw from heauens hight,
Such one, as that same mighty man of God,
With bloudy letters by the hand of God,
The new Hierusalem, that God has built
More deare vnto their God, then you[n]glings to their dam.
Then shall I soone, (quoth he) so God me grace,
The God of warre with his fiers equipage
That I this man of God his godly armes may blaze.
And gan to highest God entirely pray,
It chaunst (eternall God that chaunce did guide)
Great God it planted in that blessed sted
Then God she praysd, and thankt her faithfull knight,
And well arriued are, (high God be blest)
High God be witnesse, that I guiltlesse ame.
Would God thy selfe now present were in place,
So God ye speed, and send you good successe;
And said, Faire sonne, God giue you happie chance,
God guide thee, Guyon, well to end thy warke,
Such and such euill God on Guyon reare,
Or that high God, in lieu of innocence,
In them the blinded god his lustfull fire
Before her gate high God did Sweat ordaine,
Ah God, what horrour and tormenting griefe
God of the world and worldlings I me call,
Great Mammon, greatest god below the skye,
Eternall God thee saue from such decay.
Suffise it then, thou Money God (quoth hee)
As if that highest God defie he would;
The God, though loth, yet was constraind t'obay,
Of highest God, that loues his creatures so,
